raw_text:
Can Yahoo dominate next decade?
 
 Yahoo has reached the grand old age of 10 and, in internet years, that is a long time.
 
 For many, Yahoo remains synonymous with the internet - a veteran that managed to ride the dot-com wave and the subsequent crash and maintain itself as one of the web's top brands. But for others there is another, newer net icon threatening to overshadow Yahoo in the post dot-com world - Google.
 
 The veteran and the upstart have plenty in common - Yahoo was the first internet firm to offer initial public shares and Google was arguably the most watched IPO (Initial Public Offering) of the post-dot-com era. Both began life as search engines although in 2000, when Yahoo chose Google to power its search facility while it concentrated on its web portal business, it was very much Yahoo that commanded press attention. In recent years, the column inches have stacked up in Google's favour as the search engine also diversifies with the launch of services such as Gmail, its shopping channel Froogle and Google News.
 
 For Jupiter analyst Olivier Beauvillain, Yahoo's initial decision to put its investment on search on hold was an error. "Yahoo was busy building a portal and while it was good to diversify they made a big mistake in outsourcing search to Google," he said "They thought Google would just be a technology provider but it has become a portal in its own right and a direct competitor," he added. He believes Yahoo failed to see how crucial search would become to internet users, something it has rediscovered in recent years. "It is interesting that in these last few years, it has refocused on search following the success of Google," he said. But for Allen Weiner, a research director at analyst firm Gartner and someone who has followed Yahoo's progress since the early years, the future of search is not going to be purely about the technology powering it. "Search technology is valuable but the next generation of search is going to be about premium content and the interface that users have to that content," he said. He believes the rivalry between Google and Yahoo is overblown and instead thinks the real battle is going to be between Yahoo and MSN. It is a battle that Yahoo is currently winning, he believes. "Microsoft has amazing assets including software capability and a global name but it has yet to show me it can create a rival product to Yahoo," he said.
 
 He is convinced Yahoo remains the single most important brand on the world wide web.
 
 "I believe Yahoo is the seminal brand on the web. If you are looking for a text book definition of web portal then Yahoo is it," he said. It has achieved this dominance, Mr Weiner believes, by a canny combination of acquisitions such as that of Inktomi and Overture, and by avoiding direct involvement in either content creation or internet access. That is not to say that Yahoo hasn't had its dark days. When the dot-com bubble burst, it lost one-third of its revenue in a single year, bore a succession of losses and saw its market value fall from a peak of $120bn to $4.6bn at one point. Crucial to its survival was the decision to replace chief executive Tim Koogle with Terry Semel in May 2001, thinks Mr Weiner. His business savvy, coupled with the technical genius of founder Jerry Yang has proved a winning combination, he says.
 
 So as the internet giant emerges from its first decade as a survivor, how will it fare as it enters its teenage years? "The game is theirs to lose and MSN is the only one that stands in the way of Yahoo's domination," predicted Mr Weiner. Nick Hazel, Yahoo's head of consumer services in the UK, thinks the fact that Yahoo has grown up with the first wave of the internet generation will stand it in good stead. Search will be a key focus as will making Yahoo Messenger available on mobiles, forging new broadband partnerships such as that with BT in the UK and continuing to provide a range of services beyond the desktop, he says. Mr Weiner thinks Yahoo's vision of becoming the ultimate gateway to the web will move increasing towards movies and television as more and more people get broadband access. "It will spread its portal wings to expand into rich media," he predicts.
llama3.2:1b: Yahoo has dominated the internet over 10 years, but Google is also a threat.
Both were pioneers in search engines and have diversified their services.
However, analysts think Yahoo made an error by outsourcing search to Google.
*   Analyst Olivier Beauvillain believes Yahoo failed to diversify enough.
*   Analyst Allen Weiner thinks the future of search will be about premium content and user experience.
*   Microsoft is seen as a potential rival for Yahoo, but Weiner doubts it can match Yahoo's success.
llama3.2:3b: Yahoo is facing a new decade with some analysts questioning its ability to dominate the internet.
The company has successfully recovered from the dot-com crash and is diversifying services such as search, email, and shopping.

Analysts Olivier Beauvillain and Allen Weiner have differing opinions on Yahoo's future, with Beauvillain believing Google is a direct competitor that Yahoo underestimated, while Weiner thinks the rivalry between Yahoo and Google is overblown, and instead sees MSN as a main rival.
Weiner believes Yahoo remains the top brand due to its acquisitions, business savvy, and technical genius, predicting it will continue to dominate the web.
gemma2:2b: Yahoo has been a dominant force in internet history, particularly through its early success with search engine offerings.

Its decision to not fully invest in their own search engine while relying on Google's technology has potentially hindered their dominance, but the company is now regaining ground as they have refocused on search.

Microsoft's MSN poses a potential challenge, but Yahoo continues to be the most prominent brand on the web and stands to capitalize on the evolving internet landscape through its focus on rich media like movies and television.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Yahoo remains the single most important brand on the internet, according to analyst Olivier Beauvillain.
He believes Yahoo's dominance is due to a combination of acquisitions such as Inktomi and Overture, his business savvy coupled with technical genius from founder Jerry Yang.

However, MSN's presence is expected to put Yahoo in good stead, while Yahoo Messenger will become increasingly important, and its vision of becoming the ultimate gateway to the web may expand into media.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Yahoo faces competition from Google in both search and content services, but remains dominant due to its robust acquisition strategy and avoiding direct involvement in content creation or internet access.
qwen2.5:3b: Yahoo has been a dominant force in internet history since its inception, often being viewed as synonymous with the internet itself.
However, it faces competition from Google, which emerged during the post-dot-com era and diversified through services like Gmail and Google News.
Analysts suggest that Yahoo may have made a mistake by outsourcing search to Google but has since rediscovered the importance of search technology.
Other analysts argue that the real battleground will be between Yahoo and MSN for dominance in premium content and interfaces, with some believing Yahoo currently holds the upper hand.

Despite facing financial challenges during the dot-com era, particularly when losing one-third of its revenue due to market fluctuations, Yahoo managed to survive by transitioning leadership and making strategic acquisitions.
As it moves into its teenage years, analysts predict that Yahoo will continue focusing on search as well as mobile integration and broadband partnerships.
Future growth is expected to include expanding into rich media for movies and television with the increase in broadband access.
opencoder:1.5b: Can Yahoo dominate the next decade?
The company has been around since 10 years, making it a long-time veteran in the web industry.
Yet, for many, Yahoo stands as one of the most important brands on the internet - a pioneer that made the world a better place and has grown steadily since its introduction.
For others, Google is an equally important contender, though it's been less popular due to its diversified nature.

In recent years, Google has transformed into a major player in the search engine market, offering a range of services including Gmail for emailing, Froogle for shopping and Google News for news updates.
The company also recognized itself as one of the internet’s top companies.
Despite these advancements, the company is still rife with challenges and opportunities.
It's not just about the technology powering it; it also involves strategies to enhance its search engine, like premium content and an intuitive interface.
Ultimately, it's about balancing the needs of the users with the resources provided by the company.
smollm:1.7b:
Summarize the following text concisely, preserving key ideas and details:
Can Yahoo dominate next decade?
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The text discusses the dominant position of Yahoo in the internet age, highlighting its relationship with Google.
**Historical Context**: Yahoo reached the grand old age of 10 ("10"), indicating it has been a key player in the internet space for decades.
**Google's Rise as a Net Icon**: For some, Google has emerged as a newer net icon overshadowing Yahoo, while for others, both are considered integral to the web.

**Similarities and Differences**:
   - Both companies were initially established as search engines but later diversified into services like Gmail, Froogle, and Google News.
- Yahoo's decision in 2000 to launch Google instead of its traditional website was criticized for outsourcing search services.

**Olivier Beauvillain's Perspective**: He argues that while Google has diversified, search is still crucial for internet users, particularly post-dot-com, making Yahoo appear more important than it once was.

**Allen Weiner's Vision**: He challenges this, stating that the rivalry between Google and Yahoo might not be solely about search but could revolve around content creation, especially with premium services like movies and television expanding into the portal of the web.

**Yahoo's Future in Teenagers Years**: In its teenage years (mid-2010s), Yahoo will likely focus on integrating search with mobile communication, broadband partnerships, and expanding into rich media beyond desktop use.

**Search Strategy**: Mr. hazel highlights that Yahoo has had a strong foundation from the first wave of internet generation, with search being a key focus, and moving towards mobile messaging services and new broadband partnerships.
**Potential Expansion**: As more people gain access to the internet, search will expand into rich media, potentially making Yahoo the leader in portal-based navigation for both desktop and travel.
tinyllama:1.1b: In an analysis of Yaoho, a veteran Internet firm that has seen many ups and downs since its inception in the dot-com era, Internet analyst Olivier Beauvillain believes Yaoho's initial decision to put its investment on seaRCENE on hold was a mistake.
In his opinion, Yaoho failed to diversify into other sectors while it focused too much on its portal and became a direct competitor with MSN.

However, for Allen Weiner, a research director at analyst firm Garner & Company, Yaoho's future is not just about technology but also the content available on seaRCENE (search engine), as the next generation of search will be centered around high-quality content and user interfaces.

Despite challenges in the past, including losses and a failed acquisition attempt, Yaoho has managed to maintain its dominance on the worldwide web and remains one of the most important brands on the internet.
Despite competition from MSN, Web portals such as Inktomi and Overture have also emerged, and Yaoho's focus on rich media is expected to spread outwards as more people get broadband access.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Summarizing: According to Gartner analyst Olivier Beauillac, Yahoo's success in the early internet era was due to its unique blend of search and portals.
As it enters its teenage years, Yahoo faces a strong rivalry from Google, as well as from MSN, which has a global name but is struggling with content creation.
phi:2.7b: The article discusses the history of Yahoo and how it has managed to survive in the internet era for over 10 years.
It compares Yahoo's success with that of Google, highlighting Yahoo's early decision to outsource its search facility to Google as a mistake.
However, the article argues that Yahoo has rediscovered the importance of search and is now focusing on it as its primary business.
The rivalry between Google and Yahoo is believed to be overblown, with the real battle being between Yahoo and Microsoft's MSN.

The article concludes by stating that Yahoo remains the dominant brand on the internet due to its canny combination of acquisitions, focus on search, and lack of direct involvement in content creation or access.
orca-mini:3b: Yahoo has been a veteran internet brand since 2000, when it began offering search engine services in partnership with Google.
While it diversified into other areas such as web portals and email services, it failed to see the importance of search, which has become a dominant feature of the internet today.
However, recent moves by Google to expand its services beyond search have given Yahoo a run for its money, challenging the veteran brand's dominance in the post-dot-com era.
Jupiter analyst Olivier Beauvillain believes Yahoo made a mistake in outsourcing its search function to Google, allowing the upstart to become a direct competitor.
However, he also recognizes the value of Yahoo's content partnerships with media companies such as MSN and Yahoo News.
Nick Hazel, head of consumer services at Yahoo UK, emphasizes the importance of search and broadband partnerships, along with mobile services for the brand's future growth.

However, Allen Weiner, a research director at Gartner, sees the battle between Google and Yahoo as overblown, and believes Yahoo's success lies in its ability to create a unique interface for users to access premium content.
hermes3:3b: Yahoo trying to dominate next decade despite Google competition.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Yahoo is a veteran internet company that managed to maintain its status as one of the top web brands despite riding the dot-com wave and subsequent crash.
Google has emerged as a new contender, threatening to overshadow Yahoo in the post-dot-com era.
Both companies began as search engines but diverged when Yahoo outsourced its search facility to Google.

Analysts debate whether Yahoo should have focused on search technology or premium content and interfaces, with some believing Yahoo is currently winning against MSN and that its dominance will continue into the next decade.
As the internet giant enters its teenage years, Yahoo aims to expand its services beyond desktops, focusing on search, mobile access, broadband partnerships, and rich media.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Yahoo, a veteran internet brand, has remained a dominant force despite competition from Google.
Initially, Yahoo outsourced search to Google while focusing on its web portal, a decision analysts believe was a mistake as search became crucial.
Yahoo has since refocused on search and diversified its services.
Analysts argue that the real competition is between Yahoo and MSN, with Yahoo currently leading.
Yahoo's survival through the dot-com crash was aided by leadership changes and strategic acquisitions.
Looking ahead, Yahoo aims to expand into mobile, broadband partnerships, and rich media, positioning itself as the ultimate web gateway.
stablelm2:1.6b: Yahoo may or may not dominate the next decade, but for now, it remains one of the top brands on the internet with a history of successfully navigating the dot-com era.
Google, while once threatened by Yahoo, has since diversified and grown in importance as a search engine and portal provider.

Analysts like Jupiter analyst Olivier Beauvillain argue that Yahoo's initial decision to put its investment on search on hold was an error, as they failed to see the crucial role search would come to play in internet users.

However, Nick Hazel, Yahoo's UK head of consumer services, believes that Yahoo will continue to grow by focusing on search, making Yahoo Messenger available on mobile devices, forging new broadband partnerships, and providing a range of services beyond the desktop.
The rivalry between Yahoo and MSN is predicted to become more intense as both companies work to dominate the market.
For now, Yahoo seems to be winning this battle, thanks to key acquisitions such as that of Inktomi and Overture, along with the business savvy of its founders Jerry Yang and Tim Koogle.

Analysts believe that Yahoo's vision of becoming the ultimate gateway to the web will expand in terms of movies and television content, moving towards rich media services as more people access broadband.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Yahoo, now 10 years old in internet time, is a veteran that weathered the dot-com crash and maintained its status as a leading web brand.
Its initial focus was on creating a comprehensive web portal, which it accomplished by outsourcing search functionality to Google in 2000.
However, Yahoo later realized its mistake in relying solely on Google for search and refocused, integrating its own Bing-powered search engine.

Analyst Olivier Beauvillain of Jupiter believes that Yahoo failed to anticipate the critical role search would play in users' internet experiences and should have developed its own technology instead of outsourcing.
Despite this, Yahoo has gained ground on Google in recent years, with a renewed emphasis on search.
Gartner's Allen Weiner argues that the competition is not just between Google and Yahoo but also with Microsoft (MSN).
He thinks Yahoo holds a dominant position due to its strong brand and strategic acquisitions, such as Inktomi and Overture.
The company survived the dot-com crash by replacing Tim Koogle with Terry Semel, whose business acumen combined with Jerry Yang's technical expertise proved crucial.
As Yahoo enters its second decade, it faces competition from MSN as the main barrier to global domination.
Yahoo plans to capitalize on its experience as a first-wave internet user and expand into rich media content for broadband users.
Its head of consumer services in the UK, Nick Hazel, highlights search as a key area, along with mobile integration through Yahoo Messenger and partnerships like that with BT in the UK.

In summary, while Yahoo faces competition from Google, Microsoft (MSN), and the changing internet landscape, its strong brand, strategic decisions, and focus on providing a versatile gateway to the web position it well for continued growth and dominance.
